title: betaNB: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
text: Generates nonparametric bootstrap confidence intervals (Efron & Tibshirani, 1993: https://doi.org/10.1201/9780429246593) standardized regression coefficients (beta) effect sizes, including multiple correlation, semipartial correlations, improvement R-squared, squared partial correlations, differences standardized regression coefficients, models fitted lm().

title: betaNB: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
text: can install CRAN release betaNB : can install development version betaNB GitHub :

title: betaNB: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
text: example, multiple regression model fitted using program quality ratings (QUALITY) regressand/outcome variable number published articles attributed program faculty members (NARTIC), percent faculty members holding research grants (PCTGRT), percentage program graduates received support (PCTSUPP) regressor/predictor variables using data set 1982 ratings 46 doctoral programs psychology USA [@NationalResearchCouncil-1982]. Confidence intervals standardized regression coefficients generated using BetaNB() function betaNB package.

title: betaNB: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
text: Fit regression model using lm() function.
code: object <- lm(QUALITY ~ NARTIC + PCTGRT + PCTSUPP, data = df)

title: betaNB: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
betaNB: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
betaNB: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
text: betaNB package also functions generate nonparametric bootstrap confidence intervals effect sizes RSqNB() multiple correlation coefficients (R-squared adjusted R-squared), DeltaRSqNB() improvement R-squared, SCorNB() semipartial correlation coefficients, PCorNB() squared partial correlation coefficients, DiffBetaNB() differences standardized regression coefficients.

title: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
text: Ivan Jacob Agaloos Pesigan 2025-10-18

title: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
text: Generates nonparametric bootstrap confidence intervals (Efron & Tibshirani, 1993: https://doi.org/10.1201/9780429246593) standardized regression coefficients (beta) effect sizes, including multiple correlation, semipartial correlations, improvement R-squared, squared partial correlations, differences standardized regression coefficients, models fitted lm().

title: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
text: can install CRAN release betaNB : can install development version betaNB GitHub :

title: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
text: example, multiple regression model fitted using program quality ratings (QUALITY) regressand/outcome variable number published articles attributed program faculty members (NARTIC), percent faculty members holding research grants (PCTGRT), percentage program graduates received support (PCTSUPP) regressor/predictor variables using data set 1982 ratings 46 doctoral programs psychology USA (National Research Council, 1982). Confidence intervals standardized regression coefficients generated using BetaNB() function betaNB package.

title: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
text: Fit regression model using lm() function.
code: object <- lm(QUALITY ~ NARTIC + PCTGRT + PCTSUPP, data = df)

title: Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes

Bootstrap for Regression Effect Sizes
text: betaNB package also functions generate nonparametric bootstrap confidence intervals effect sizes RSqNB() multiple correlation coefficients (R-squared adjusted R-squared), DeltaRSqNB() improvement R-squared, SCorNB() semipartial correlation coefficients, PCorNB() squared partial correlation coefficients, DiffBetaNB() differences standardized regression coefficients.

code: # Data --------------------------------------------------------------------- data("nas1982", package = "betaNB")  # Fit Model in lm ---------------------------------------------------------- object <- lm(QUALITY ~ NARTIC + PCTGRT + PCTSUPP, data = nas1982)  # NB ----------------------------------------------------------------------- nb <- NB(   object,   R = 100, # use a large value e.g., 5000L for actual research   seed = 0508 )  # DiffBetaNB --------------------------------------------------------------- out <- DiffBetaNB(nb, alpha = 0.05)  ## Methods ----------------------------------------------------------------- print(out) #> Call: #> DiffBetaNB(object = nb, alpha = 0.05) #>  #> Differences of standardized regression slopes #> type = "pc" #>                   est     se   R    2.5%  97.5% #> NARTIC-PCTGRT  0.1037 0.1283 100 -0.1579 0.3251 #> NARTIC-PCTSUPP 0.2319 0.1271 100  0.0284 0.4791 #> PCTGRT-PCTSUPP 0.1282 0.1326 100 -0.1146 0.3731 summary(out) #> Call: #> DiffBetaNB(object = nb, alpha = 0.05) #>  #> Differences of standardized regression slopes #> type = "pc" #>                   est     se   R    2.5%  97.5% #> NARTIC-PCTGRT  0.1037 0.1283 100 -0.1579 0.3251 #> NARTIC-PCTSUPP 0.2319 0.1271 100  0.0284 0.4791 #> PCTGRT-PCTSUPP 0.1282 0.1326 100 -0.1146 0.3731 coef(out) #>  NARTIC-PCTGRT NARTIC-PCTSUPP PCTGRT-PCTSUPP  #>      0.1036564      0.2318974      0.1282410  vcov(out) #>                NARTIC-PCTGRT NARTIC-PCTSUPP PCTGRT-PCTSUPP #> NARTIC-PCTGRT    0.016459509    0.007515380   -0.008944129 #> NARTIC-PCTSUPP   0.007515380    0.016165350    0.008649969 #> PCTGRT-PCTSUPP  -0.008944129    0.008649969    0.017594099 confint(out, level = 0.95) #>                      2.5 %    97.5 % #> NARTIC-PCTGRT  -0.15787042 0.3250606 #> NARTIC-PCTSUPP  0.02839849 0.4790846 #> PCTGRT-PCTSUPP -0.11463617 0.3730821
